awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSI: REAL-TIME LARGE-SCALE PARALLEL INTELLIGENT CO2 DATA ASSIMILATION SYSTEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: This proposal seeks to address this need by creating a state-of-the-art autonomous software platform for real-time integration of in-situ and satellite-based atmospheric CO2 measurements within a Data Assimilation (DA) system for producing estimates of global land and oceanic CO2 exchange at weekly to bi-weekly intervals. The proposed software infrastructure will be capable of autonomous processing of large volumes of data through a multi-stage pipeline, without the delays conventionally associated with such processing. Within the DA component, we will provide options for multiple DA algorithms for estimating global CO2 exchange. Users will, for the first time, have the capability to use these multiple methods as part of a single system for comparing estimates of CO2 exchange, and to obtain an improved understanding of the relative advantages of the various DA methods. As part of the analysis component of the software, we will build a carbon-climate surveillance system by drawing from a range of techniques in pattern recognition and high-dimensional statistical inference. This system will be able to detect and analyze localized variations in CO2 exchange within any user-specified spatio-temporal window. In addition, summaries of the CO2 exchange will be provided at annual and monthly temporal scales for continents and countries.

Broader Impacts: This software can be used by researchers and governmental institutions for evaluating both the natural components of the carbon cycle and anthropogenic carbon emissions, as well as in the design of new satellites for improved monitoring of CO2. All data and software will be publicly available and open-source development platforms will be used whenever possible.  The algorithm prototypes developed as part of this project will be used in undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Michigan, and will be made available online for educators at other institutions. Finally, the project will train three graduate students, with a focus on developing their cross-disciplinary skills in the field of Earth science, statistics, computer science, and atmospheric science.

por.por_cntn:
REAL-TIME LARGE-SCALE PARALLEL INTELLIGENT CO2 DATA ASSIMILATION SYSTEM

 

Increasing concentrations of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) are recognized as the main driver of climate change. Data assimilation models are regarded as one of the primary tools that can be used to quantify CO2 exchange or fluxes (out-flow/in-flow of CO2 in and out of the atmosphere) and have the capability to provide actionable diagnostic and prognostic information in support of the design, implementation and periodic re-assessment of carbon management policies. However, there exists no software system that has (1) a capacity to ingest high volumes of CO2 data in a timely fashion for producing global estimates of CO2 exchange, (2) a modular architecture capable of evaluating different modeling approaches, and (3) the capability to estimate CO2 exchange at better than annual intervals. Moreover, early warning capabilities linked to these models to detect unexpected features (i.e., anomalies) in both natural (e.g. arctic permafrost thaw) and anthropogenic (e.g., unexpected increases in fossil fuel emissions) carbon exchange is also absent in existing data assimilation models.

To overcome these deficiencies, in this project, we formulated and developed a prototypical framework where observations of spatially and temporally varying CO2 concentrations (amount of CO2 by volume of air) in the atmosphere are ingested in multiple data assimilation modeling frameworks to spatially and temporally locate sources of CO2 exchange. The primary goal of this work was to seamlessly integrate Data-Acquisition/Data-Assimilation/Analysis/Visualization (for details see, https://dge.carnegiescience.edu/labs

/michalaklab/CO2DAAD/index.html) into a single parallel operational system designed to ingest in-situ and satellite-based observations of CO2 concentrations to reduce latency in computing CO2 exchange from years to months. Other goals of the project were to (1) develop a surveillance system that can be deployed to identify impacts of burning fossil fuels and sudden and gradual natural events (e.g., fires and droughts) on regional and global CO2 exchange and (2) statistically identify similarities or dissimilarities between the maps of CO2 exchange obtained by using two different sets of data assimilation models that estimate CO2 exchange.

The research facilitated by the project led to the development of a software system that gathers available data from diverse web sources, assembles these data, and layers on top of this subsystem data assimilation models that compute CO2 exchange. Further these data are processed within a database for visualization. The code for these sub-systems i.e., Data-Acquisition, Data-Assimilation and Visualization is available at https://dge.carnegiescience.edu/

labs/michalaklab/CO2DAAD/index.html. In addition, we developed (1) a formulation of a matrix multiplication algorithm for multiplication of factorable matrices with an arbitrary matrix that significantly reduced the time for multiplying these matrices (code is downloadable from: https://www.geosci-model-dev.net/6/583/2013/gmd-6-583-2013-supplement.zip), (3) efficient methods for computing uncertainties in data assimilation or inverse models (code is downloadable from: https://www.geosci-model-dev.net/6/583/2013/gmd-6-583-2013-

supplement.zip), (4) software that specially addressed the computational efficiency of matrix multiplication of two sparse matrices that results in symmetric dense matrices (code is downloadable from https://www.geosci-model-dev-discuss.net/gmd-2016-204/gmd-2016-204-supplement.zip), and (5) non-parametric statistical and machine learning methods for identifying anomalies in climate and/or CO2 exchange data that are unlabeled, i.e., data for which ground truth labels for anomalies like fires and droughts are not available. These methods have the capability to reliably recover the normal distribution in these data in the presence of small amounts of contamination (i.e., when anomalies are present in the data).

The project resulted in 28 peer-reviewed publications. It also resulted in the research and cross-training of 2 undergraduate, 6 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral researchers in both the underlying science as will as the computer science aspects of the work. The software tools developed as part of this work, are presently being used by researchers and governmental institutions for evaluating both the natural components of the carbon cycle and anthropogenic carbon emissions, an example of which is the development of CarbonTracker-Lagrange at NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory (for details, see https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/carbontracker-lagrange/). Overall, the software and methodological development performed as part of the project laid the future foundation that has eased assimilation of large volumes of CO2 observations from multiple data streams with different sensor geometries, and has also helped in the assessment of the utility of simultaneous assimilation of data from an observing system comprising of vehicles, aircraft, drones, ground-based, and satellite sensors in monitoring the global carbon cycle and atmospheric exchange of other greenhouse gases such as methane. Notably, the methods developed as part of this work have wide applicability beyond the scope of the project, especially the matrix multiplication methods, which can be utilized to increase computational efficiency of a wide variety of statistical and machine learning methods.
